anchor.surface_text: 1958. January 22. The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR J.-The respondent, a scheduled

facts.text: Respondent is a scheduled bank.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, a scheduled bank, sued the appellant in the companyrt of the Civil Judge, Sitapore in Uttar

facts.text: Respondent sued appellant in court of Civil Judge Sitapur Uttar Pradesh for recovery of money due under mortgage instrument.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, a scheduled bank, sued the appellant in the companyrt of the Civil Judge, Sitapore in Uttar Pradesh, for the recovery of money due under an instrument of mortgage.

facts.text: Suit No. 16 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 357 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 28, 1956, of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  in Misc. Case No. 4 of 1955 and Civil Revision No. 189 of 1955, arising out of the order dated August 6, 1955 of the Civil Judge, Sitapur in Suit No. 16 of 1953.

facts.text: Appellant contested the suit on several grounds including entitlement to relief under Uttar Pradesh Zamindars Debt Reduction Act U.P. XV of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytested the suit on several grounds one of which was that he was entitled to relief under the Uttar Pradesh Zamindars Debt Reduction Act  U.P. XV of 1953  which reduced the amount

facts.text: U.P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act XV of 1953 defines debt as advance in cash or kind excluding advances on or after July 1, 1952 and debts due to scheduled banks.

anchor.surface_text: Now a debt was defined in the Act in these terms 2 f  debt means an advance in cash or in kind and includes any transaction which is in substance a debt but does number include an advance as aforesaid made on or after the first day of July, 1952 or a debt due to- the Central Government or Government of any State a local authority a scheduled bank a companyoperative society and 1152 a waqf, trust or endowment for a charitable or religious purpose only.

facts.text: Debt due to respondent scheduled bank not a debt under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: As the respondent was a scheduled bank the debt due to it from the appellant was number a debt within this definition and companysequently, numberrelief would appear to be available to the appellant under the Act in respect of that debt.

facts.text: Appellant contended that definition excluding certain debts offends Article 14 of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, however, companytended that the definition in so far as it excluded certain debts offended Art. 14 of the Constitution in as much as it made an arbitrary distinction between several classes of debtors and denied the excluded debtors, the equal protection of the law

facts.text: Appellant applied to Civil Judge Sitapur under proviso to s.113 CPC to state case to High Court on validity.

anchor.surface_text: This defence, therefore, raised a question as to the validity of a provision in the Act. So the appellant made an application to the Civil Judge, Sitapur, under the proviso to s. 113 of the Code of Civil Procedure asking him to state a case for the opinion of the High Court at Allahabad

facts.text: Civil Judge held impugned portion invalid under Art 14 but not necessary to decide as not severable.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Civil Judge took the view that the impugned portion of the definition infringed art. 14 of the Constitution as it made an arbitrary distinction between several classes of debtors and was therefore invalid, but he held that it was number necessary for the disposal of the case to decide such question of invalidity because even if it was decided in favour of the appellant, the result would be to exclude the entire definition from the Act as the offending portion was number severable from the rest

facts.text: Civil Judge dismissed application under proviso to s.113 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellant would, therefore, be in any event left without the protection of the Act. In this view of the matter he held that the proviso to s. 113 of the Code did number apply and dismissed the application under it.

facts.text: Appellant filed application to High Court for revision of Civil Judge order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then made an application to the High Court at Allahabad for a revision of the order of the learned Civil Judge.

facts.text: Appellant filed application to High Court under Art. 228 Constitution to withdraw case.

anchor.surface_text: He at the same time made another application to the High Court under Art. 228 of the Constitution. That article is in these terms If the High Court is satisfied that a case pending in a companyrt subordinate to it involves a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of this Constitution

facts.text: High Court dismissed revision and Art. 228 application by one judgment dated February 28, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court disposed of both the applications by one judgment. It held that there was numberdispute as to the companystitutional principle which was clear, namely, that every citizen was entitled to the equal protection of the laws

facts.text: High Court held no question of constitutional interpretation, only construction of Act, not necessary for disposal.

anchor.surface_text: and that the only dispute was whether the impugned portion of the definition of a debt in the Act was severable from the rest and that was number a question of the interpretation of any provision of the Constitution but one of the companystruction of the Act itself.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal holding question of validity necessary for disposal of case.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that it is necessary to decide the question of the validity of the impugned part of the definition to dispose of the case. This appeal is hence allowed.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 28, 1956, of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  in Misc. Case No. 4 of 1955
Misc. Case No. 4 of 1955 and Civil Revision No. 189 of 1955, arising out of the order dated August 6, 1955 of the Civil Judge, Sitapur in Suit No. 16 of 1953.

issues.text: Whether the exclusion of certain debts from the definition of 'debt' under section 2(f) of the U.P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act offended Article 14 of the Constitution by making an arbitrary distinction between classes of debtors?

anchor.surface_text: offended Art. 14 of the Constitution in as much as it made an arbitrary distinction between several classes of debtors and denied the excluded debtors, the equal protection of the law and that hence that portion of the definition which excluded certain debts was invalid

issues.text: Whether it is necessary for the disposal of the case to decide the question of the validity of the impugned portion of the definition of 'debt'?

anchor.surface_text: The point that really arises in this appeal is whether it is necessary for the disposal of the case to decide the question of the validity of a portion of the definition of a debt in the Act . All other conditions necessary for an order being made under the proviso to s. 113 of the Code or Art. 228 of the Constitution exist

issues.text: Whether the question of the validity of the impugned provision constitutes a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution under Article 228?

anchor.surface_text: This question is, however, also a question as to the interpretation of the Constitution, for the validity of the provision is challenged on the ground that it contravenes an article of the Constitution. The point that really arises in this appeal is whether it is necessary

issues.text: Whether the impugned portion of the definition of 'debt' is severable from the rest of the definition?

arguments.claim: Conditions for proviso to s.113 CPC and Art.228 are satisfied except possibly necessity, but necessity exists

anchor.surface_text: The point that really arises in this appeal is whether it is necessary for the disposal of the case to decide the question of the validity of a portion of the definition of a debt in the Act . All other conditions necessary for an order being made under the proviso to s. 113 of the Code or Art. 228 of the Constitution exist

holdings.text: This question is, however, also a question as to the interpretation of the Constitution, for the validity of the provision is challenged on the ground that it contravenes an article of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This question is, however, also a question as to the interpretation of the Constitution, for the validity of the provision is challenged on the ground that it contravenes an article of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Challenge to validity of statutory provision on ground of contravention of constitutional article constitutes question of interpretation of the Constitution.

holdings.text: We, therefore, hold that it is necessary to decide the question of the validity of the impugned part of the definition to dispose of the case.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that it is necessary to decide the question of the validity of the impugned part of the definition to dispose of the case. This appeal is hence allowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Validity question raised and pressed by appellant must be decided for disposal; severability arises only after invalidity determined and cannot be pre-judged to avoid deciding validity.

holdings.text: The question as to the severability of the impugned part of the definition from the rest would arise only after it had been decided that the impugned part was invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The question as to the severability of the impugned part of the definition from the rest would arise only after it had been decided that the impugned part was invalid and so to be able to say that the impugned part of the definition was not severable from the rest, it had first to be held that that part was invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical sequence requires deciding invalidity before assessing severability; cannot presuppose invalidity and non-severability to deem validity question unnecessary.

holdings.text: It seems clear to us that the question raised by the appellant in this case comes within the proviso to s. 113 of the Code as also art. 228 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: From this judgment the present appeal has been filed. It seems clear to us that the question raised by the appellant in this case comes within the proviso to s. 113 of the Code as also art. 228 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Question of statutory validity on constitutional grounds satisfies jurisdictional requirements of both provisions apart from necessity condition.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that it is necessary to decide the question of the validity of the impugned part of the definition to dispose of the case. This appeal is hence allowed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; court held that it is necessary to decide the question of the validity of the impugned part of the definition to dispose of the case
